newsitem.title: USA: Nervous bond market rattles weekly mortgage rates.
newsitem.headline: Nervous bond market rattles weekly mortgage rates.

text.p: A jittery bond market pushed the U.S. 30-year fixed-rate mortgage up to an average 7.74 percent in the week ending Dec 20 from 7.57 percent the previous week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp said Thursday.

Freddie Mac said the average commitment rate on 15-year mortgages rose to 7.21 percent from 7.06 percent in the prior week. Both the 30- and 15-year loans were at their highest levels since early November.
Adjustable-rate mortgages rose to an average 5.53 percent in the latest week from 5.52 percent in the preceding week.
A year ago, the 30-year rate averaged 7.23 percent, the 15-year 6.73 percent, and the ARM 5.64 percent.

"Because of the better-than-expected figures in the housing starts report released this week (by the Commerce Department), the bond market got a little jittery, causing interest rates to rise," Freddie Mac chief economist Robert Van Order said.

Freddie Mac said lenders charged an average 1.8 percent in fees and points on 30- and 15-year loans in the week, both up from 1.4 percent last week. They charged 1.4 percent on ARM loans, unchanged from the previous week.
